introduction.p: Two concetric metal spherical shells make up a spherical capacitor.

sidebyside.p:
The capacitance of a spherical capacitor with radii R_1 \lt R_2 of shells without anything between the plates is
C = 4\pi\epsilon_0\, \left( \dfrac{1}{R_1} - \dfrac{1}{R_2} \right)^{-1}.

introduction.p:
We have seen before that if we have a material of dielectric constant \epsilon_r filling the space between plates, the capacitance in will increase by a factor of the dielectric constant.
C = 4\pi\epsilon_0\epsilon_r\, \left( \dfrac{1}{R_1} - \dfrac{1}{R_2} \right)^{-1}.

To prove the formula given in Eq. , we place positive +Q on the inner shell and -Q on the outer shell. We will find potential difference V and then get C from Q/V. To find the potential between the plates, we integrate electric field from negative plate to positive plate. Therefore, we first find electric field between the plates.

With zero of potential at r=\infty, potential difference can be shown by integrating -\vec E\cdot d\vec r = -E dr from r=R_2 to r=R_1. If you are working through this book with a Calculus background you should do that integral. For others, I will just give the result.
V = \phi_+ - \phi_- = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\, \left( \dfrac{Q}{R_1} - \dfrac{Q}{R_2} \right).
From this we get the capacitance by finding V/Q.
C = 4\pi\epsilon_0\, \left( \dfrac{1}{R_1} - \dfrac{1}{R_2} \right)^{-1}.
It is interesting to note that you can get capacitance of a single spherical conductor from this formula by taking the radius of the outer shell to infinity, R_2\rightarrow \infty. Since we will have only one sphere, let us denote its radius by R.
C_\text{single sphere} = 4\pi\epsilon_0\, R.

statement.p: A spherical capacitor has following radii R_1=1\text{ cm} and R_2=2\text{ cm}. There is nothing in the space between the two conductors. (a) What is its capacitance? (b) What will be the capacitor if the space between the two shells is filled with mica of dielectric constant \epsilon_r = 7.0?

hint.p: Use formula given in this section.

solution.title: (a)
(a)
solution.p:
The capacitance with dielectric filling all of space between he plates is simple multiple of that with vacuum there.
C = 7 \times 7.4\times 10^{-13}\text{ F} = 5.2\text{ pF}.

exercise.title: Voltage of a Charged Metal Sphere

statement.p: A copper ball of radius 2.5\text{ cm} has 5.0\,\mu\text{C} of charge. What is its potential with respect to infinity?

hint.p: You can use single sphere capacitor formula.

solution.p:
Although we can solve this problem couple of different ways, I will just use the capacitance formula for a single sphere and the Q=CV for a capacitor.
C \amp = 4\pi\epsilon_0\, R \amp = \frac{0.025}{9\times 10^{9}} = 2.78\times 10^{-12}\text{ F}.
Therefore,
V = \frac{Q}{C} = \frac{5.0\times 10^{-6}}{2.78\times 10^{-12}} = 1.8\times 10^{6}\text{ V}.
